author: TLilico90

text:
Tesla and electric cars in general are a scam. I am not against electric cars, I think it's a great future technology, but it's not a technology that is ready for the present day, and it's not needed. 

A range of 300 miles? That sounds awesome, until you realize they are talking about potential maximum range on a perfectly smooth test track, and so long as you keep the engine at optimum RPM the whole way, you don't go up hills, you don't turn on your lights or heating or anything else, and don't drive anywhere cold.  And building these cars is paid for more by the taxpayer than the manufacturer; it's a subsidy based industry.

Engine efficiency in electric cars is inferior to gasoline vehicles; about 30% for a typical budget car compared to 25% for an electric car. And batteries are heavy. Gasoline is pretty light, and you can run the car on a 1/4 tank. Who is going to pay for the fast-charging stations? We are going to need a hell of a lot of them. More taxpayer subsidies? And what about power stations? We will need lots of nuclear power stations built to provide electricity for all these tens of millions of electric cars? 

And even if you think carbon emissions are bad (they're not) electric cars generate more carbon than regular cars, plus several very toxic chemicals used for production.Ôªø

text:
Self driving cars will not be a thing until "human error">(non self driving cars) are eliminated, or else the whole concept is dead. I mean whats the point of making self driving cars if they cannot even think fast enough and make assumptions. Google is making them only because they want more people to use google. I mean what else would you be doing in those things besides social media. Tesla is a battery company advertising and developing batteries to store renewable energy for domestic use. And Cadillac's CT6 is just being a cadillac and using new technology. Back to the point, in order for there to be actual functioning driverless cars that eliminate human error, they have to all be driverless at the same time. This means that some how the government is gonna have to get rid of all non driverless cars at one time. And they will need to pay a ton of money to redesign roads. And either give everyone driverless cars or make people pay for them. This will piss everyone off so, no. there won't be driverless cars that prevent "human error" unless they are used as driverless "cruse controls". Or an artificial intelligence that everyone can afford to have in their car. Oh and one more thing computers malfunction! there will probably be a lawsuit if that causes a fatality. :P

Just imagine it you are in your perfect driverless car going like, 60 mph. drinking your coffee. It starts to rain and a wire gets exposed to it because of, you know wear and tear. Theres a corner coming up and the car slowly eases the throttle. THEN zap the wire shorts out and the front wheels get locked up. you reach for the driving wheel! wait there is none. RRRRAA SKID BANG THUD!!! (Screams)6 seconds later you are at the bottom of the cliff DEAD. Well at least you avoided a small "fender bender" like 2 years back.XDÔªø

author: Areeb Azeem

text:
Here are some car trends I mock right now.

1.  Ridiculously shaped and expensive headlight and taillight housings to make your car look like it has a cutesy face on it.

2. Factory pickup trucks that are 8ft tall with a bed that is 4ft tall, and need a special lowering hitch to tow anything.

3. Car engines with pointless plastic covers.

4. AWD minivans.

5. Gigantic front grills on trucks and SUVs.

6. Large wheels and low-sidewall-height tires.

7. Headlights with mini windshield wipers.

8. Auxiliary batteries.

9. No accessible fuel filter.

10. Pneumatic cylinders on hoods instead of a prop-stick.

11. Daytime running headlights.Ôªø

author: Neon Dragger

text: Number One: The fact that most people don't use pickup trucks and SUVs, aka Stupid Ugly Vehicles, as they were meant to be used, specifically for off-roading and/or hauling heavy things. Not for showing off and compensating for something.Ôªø
author: Christopher0184

text:
That's something really annoying here in the US. Hell, I love pickup trucks and SUVs, actually my daily driver is a 1998 Chevrolet K2500HD Extended Cab Long Bed with the L65 turbo-diesel, but since I live out in the countryside, at the end of a dirt road that will get your vehicle bogged down in heavy rain, and not to mention I don't haul asses around but my need to carry/tow heavy/large loads is constant, I consider myself different from those posers. You know, I would even appreciate them even more if they are either used for work, or off-roading. I feel disgusted looking at the "higher-end" pickup trucks/SUVs and their price tags. If I want a luxury car, I would save up (you only need your determination) and buy a goddamn Bentley Mulsanne Speed, which is my dream luxury ride. Much more class, luxurious, beautiful, purposeful, quality, and quieter than any high-end trim pickup trucks/SUVs, not to mention diesel-grade torque at low engine speed and sports car performance.
The fact that the EPA or the goverment doesn't ban using SUVs/pickup trucks like normal cars is ridiculous. I mean, come on, most SUVs and 1/2-ton pickup trucks are gasoline-powered, and they drink lots of gas and emit lots of harmful emission compared to a sedan due to their weight and engine size, and yet they put more emission control stuff like EGR and DPF to our diesel engines, which are mainly used on commercial/industrial vehicles, which are work vehicles. I understand the purpose of emission control and I support it, but they should begin at the right place. And that's one more reason I love older pickup trucks/SUVs: no electronic driver aids (ABS, ESP, traction control, etc.) and manual transmissions are standard, not to mention the use of solid axle front and rear (both 4x2 and 4x4, though this is generally before 1990s). They are a more accurate reflection of their purposes, far different from their modern successors.Ôªø

text: I've never met a human that can do the things most programs do. Computers are far more adept at what they do than humans are. The catch? Computers can't think for themselves, or be self-aware. They can only do the one thing. Running the Google back-end, driving a car, flying an aircraft. It's incredibly easy to beat a human at any one particular task, but to beat a human in the massive range of things a human can do; impossible with current technology. That being said, your car doesn't need to cook breakfast or understand emotions. It just needs to drive. A relatively easy task for a computer to out do a human.Ôªø

author: Kevin

text:
self driving cars are an inefficient and redundant 'solution' to a problem that already has a better solution in terms of finance, management and ecological footprint. there's no reason we can't achieve it with multi tiered networks of public transport. initially the cost is high but it is cheaper and much greener long term.

the only reason you see a big fuss and lobbying about redundant self driving cars is because billion dollar business of car companies will be in trouble otherwise. there has been no good reason to buy a new model for at least a decade so they keep adding bullshit features and pack it with junk electronics to fail in a certain timeframe, turning cars into another disposable gadget.Ôªø

@zeebazu True, there really hasn't been any difference in the average car. Self driving cars shouldn't really be like taxis, because that would be no different than a bus. It should be an option for when you are tired on a road trip, or semi-autonomous, so the car immediately accelerates when it's a green light. It should be an option in cars, but not the main thingÔªø
author: Kevin

text: @BoneKRusher02 we already have those functionalities. adaptive cruise control and lane departure warning with correction. And I agree, we need assisting technologies to help us not get into fatigue. But total dependence is a bad thing. And I don't like to be the tin foil hat guy here but I have strong feeling that once they get the accuracy of self driving system higher than average human, they will eventually be phasing out people's right to drive using 'public safety' as justification.Ôªø
But anyway, those "assists" are turning us into worser drivers. People think that when their car has them they're totally safe. The driving skill is starting to die, adn we can't let that happen!Ôªø
author: kubamax9 Kubowski

text: @kubamax9 Kubowski the more assistance, the more careless people tend to become as they feel comfortable to push the limits. did you know that despite fatality rate decreasing as one would expect after 3-point seat belt was made mandatory, the number of total accidents actually increased?Ôªø
@zeebazu Heard that about somewhere. Not sure where though. But truly those assists make us weak and babyish drivers.Ôªø
author: kubamax9 Kubowski

text: @zeebazu I'm¬†not talking about safety features/assists, I'm talking about something that gets¬†cars moving immediately to¬†prevent traffic.¬†There should be a system where a car temporarily takes over if humans cannot function while getting onto a highway. Or a system that slows down when detecting that someone else is getting onto¬†the highway.¬†Things that¬†help us become better drivers. And are you liking your own comments?¬†Ôªø

author: Mr. SKYLINE

text: Yes, it is. By the way, hybrids in general are a semi-measure as far as "nature protection" goes, for the simple reason of being much heavier than a "normal" car of roughly equivalent power output. The latest Prius I 've heard of has an average combined output of 86Nm and 65Ps (pay attention, I'm mentioning its AVERAGE values) for a weight of more than 1200Kg (I don't remember the exact number though), which means very weak acceleration rates, therefore a lot of trouble in trying to keep fuel consumption down. A more powerful car, let's say for example a Caterham CSR260 (average output 197Nm and 135Ps for a three-figure weight) is far easier to drive economically without being a hurdle to other drivers. The Prius is a hurdle to other drivers... The right way to really protect the environment is to make cars as lightweight as possible, so that they use the least energy possible.Ôªø

author: Elliott_ 100

text:
I work 40 minutes from my house. There is no bus that goes between the cities in which I live, and which I work. It's a convenience feature that just would make it a more relaxing experience. Plus if you have a sports car that's worth driving, you probably aren't driving all the time, you'd probably have a secondary commute car. Also the rate of computer error over human error is MUCH lower. The rate of auto related deaths (which is 99% of the time human error) is a ridiculous number, the idea of a self driving car is theoretically orders of magnitude safer, even including the buffer from the "malfunctioning electronic shortages".

TL;DR
The hate on self-driving cars is plain stupid. The current driving system is broken. Transportation would be faster and safer don't be so inert, things like this prevent innovation and progression.Ôªø

author: Travis _

text:
to prevent crashing? BS. Those cars won't ever be able to prevent crashes, just not cause them. Proof for this is that the Tesla killed a man in a situation in which no driver on Earth paying attention would've crashed. And then Tesla comes and says "autopilot is already better than human drivers", linking to an overall crash statistic while being unable to actually prevent a crash, being one of the safest cars on the road for reasons that have nothing to do with autopilot, counting on human intervention to save the car should something happen(and if something happens, they'll probably say the human was in control, even if they took it at the final moment), and only driving on the highway, where, as we all know, accidents don't tend to happen very often. A.K.A. Misleading PR bullshit from Tesla there.

Also the Google self driving car would've caused A LOT of accidents, but was saved by the intervention of the human drivers, and then they post their data proudly saying their car made only 1-2 accidents and trying to mislead people and make them think they're not responsible. Look it up.

I partially agree on long drives, but not actually driving can make you more prone to falling asleep, and not being able to intervene in the event the car needs you, which will most likely happen on a long road.Ôªø

author: Joseph Parker

text:
stretching your tires slightly does have some small performance increase. only during cornering. When i say stretching your tires slightly, i do mean SLIGHTLY

When you stretch your tires slightly, it makes your car feel more stable and less squishy or soft when transitioning from corner to corner. 

look at a car in slow motion when initiating a corner maneuver and you can see that the side wall gets stretched until i cant any more, during that stretching, you feel a bit of a squishy or sliding feeling. it is more exaggerated in taller sidewalls. the shorter the sidewall the less this happens. so intead of stretching your tires just get lower profile tires. 

they do look nice when done properly. No, not those overly stretched tires the JDM community likes to do. no thanks

for a normal daily driver, its only going to make your car less able to soak up bumps in the road soo yeah, not a good idea.Ôªø

author: Jaey Lopidas

text: Stretching tires isn't just for style. One of the reasons people do this is to keep the standard tire from rubbing the fender well because the car sets lower and or also because the person has increased the diameter of the rim. Its hard to take a channel (Car Throttle) that claims to be in the car scene seriously when you don't even understand this basic modification. Back in the day people use to bend the fender wells out to keep the tires from rubbing. Stretching is just another way to avoid bending the sheet metal and or cutting it to install fender skirts on a set of wider/larger rims. Although, I have seen people use various combinations of bending the fender wells, adding fender skirts and or stretching the tires in order to drive without the tire rubbing. Who wants all that noise, burning rubber, and to be replacing their tires every week. NO ONE!Ôªø

text:
+Dustin DaHusky "I'd never put my life in the hands of a few sensors that still have to obey the laws of corrosion and age."

I do that all the time as do you and everyone else that goes outside. Every time I go to work, for example, I have to rely on fellow humans not having a brain fart, heart attack, brain aneurysm, a bout of Alzheimer's, sudden blindness, a moment of pure ignorance, etc, at the wrong moment and plow into me or run me off the road. I'd trust a computer system that's been properly vetted and constructed with self testing features like most cars have now and is used in the right conditions than most humans out on the roads right now.Ôªø
author: 482lost

text: Sensors can prevent accidents to a certain degree, however a driver can still override it quite easily even by mistake. Nothing is ever perfect in our world. I still think the best computer in a car is still in between the driver's ears. You must be a defensive driver where ever you go, never trust the person next to you to drive safely. Like a gun, never rely on a manual safety, you just don't know when it might fail you someday. Could be next Thursday, could be 8 months, could be 8 years, or it might never happen. Its all a guessing game. If I had sensors on my car, great, but I'd never take them too seriously. Driving defensively and being aware of who's around you does this job better and keeps you alive.¬†Ôªø

author: Palaash Atri

text:
I think too many people keep making the assumption that in the future it will HAVE to be one way or the other. Even IF every new car in the future is capable of driving itself, not everyone will want to use it. And many people will still have older cars. For instance, I drive a 31 year old pickup that still runs on a carburetor. It's a smooth, quiet, comfortable cruiser of a pickup that I use more than the other vehicles, especially for long distance. 

If I WANT a pickup with 4-wheel drive, tuned EFI, high-energy ignition, heavy-load wheels, and able to rip stumps out of the ground... then I take the other pickup. I'm in no hurry whatsoever to get rid of my NICE truck. It was parked in a shed for 20 years and still looks like new. And it's tuned so well I can start it by just reaching in the window and turning the key. 

And I frankly don't give a damn that brand-new vehicles have all sorts of new features and doodads added to them, more and more every year it seems. If and when I ever decide that these long lists of added crap are actually useful, instead of just a rainbow wig to grab everyone else's attention, I'll get one of those vehicles then. Though I'm certainly not going to go buy a new car just because it has new audio inputs, or now you can play video games on a display screen, or now there's a heating element under your butt inside the seat. The vehicles I have are already quite nice, and are very useful at comfortably driving across town. What more do I need?Ôªø

text:
TheycallmeNade - Yes, and there are too damn many people like that these days. "I really like this thing you're calling pointless or stupid, but you're going to like it too - in the future, because it gets popular, and that's all that matters here in the city..." 

No. No I won't. I already know what I like, and your opinion means less to me than a grain of sand. 

And I especially have no use for the cars you like either, children, because some of us use our vehicles in places where stoplights don't exist, and likely never will. 

For instance, I don't need or want your little shitbox battery-powered toy cars, because when I drive 600 miles on the weekend (far, far away from petty and useless city children) I consider it pretty pointless and stupid to spend 16 hours waiting for it charge it's batteries a couple of times before I can get back home.Ôªø

text: They're trying to pass some bill around to make it illegal for humans to operate vehicles after the self driving thing becomes available. Even if it's illegal I don't care I'm still driving my own car with both hands and both feet. I mean who's gonna stop me? The self driving police cars?Ôªø
author: YepItsTommy

text:
self driving police car: stop, you are driving your vehicle manually.
me: goes offroad
self driving police car: well shit.

basically I think it would be horrible, there are so many people who use cars for so much more than just their daily commute and even sometimes enjoy driving during their daily commute. Im personally getting my liscence sometime this year and am currently trying to either get a manual import for cheap like a 240sx or a classic car (the one it looks like I might be getting is a 1973 cutlass with an automatic transmition). I have loved cars ever since I was a kid and even got to ride in some of my favourites that my dad fixed up for his boss at work, my favourite was a 1966 chevelle ss with a 350. I currently do not care for driving the vehicles that I currently have or I have to use (a 2011 dodge grand caravan) but once I get my own I plan to work on it and will most likely enjoy driving. The sad thing is that I can see this hapeneing too, the government usually will try to enforce laws that will prevent death, but I personally think that it would be ridiculous to ban the driving of vehicles without computer guidance. It really is sad too, I would love to take my drivers test in my dad's 1990 chevy silverado but the view is "obstructed" by a hair thin crack in the wondshield so I cannot use that, and if that can deem a car unfit for the road then I would hate to see what would happen to their standards when self driving cars become a thing (even though nobody really cares about the more minor problems a car may have). But basically I would hate the government if they ever made that law a thing and I would most likely move to another place that allowed me to drive, even though it would probably be pretty easy to out run an automated police car by going offroad.Ôªø

author: KlockworXMusic

text: +chinchy111 - Because in general a computer can do things better then we can.  That is why there is so much stuff banned in formula 1 as far as computer aids.  Theoretically, you could give autonomous cars ability to communicate with traffic lights to know when they will change, have cars slow down, or speed up if they are in that zone where we normally decide whether to give it gas and get through a yellow, or mash the brakes.  The cars could know ahead of time when the light will change and adjust accordingly for a slight increase in speed or a more gradual stop.  So the reasoning behind why an autonomous car could be legal while driving one handed talking on a cell phone isn't is because computers are better.  If you need anymore convincing, think of it like this.  A computer can run calculations thousands upon thousands of times and second and make decisions based on that for the best outcome, but it will never get distracted by its mum talking on the phone with it about how the neighbors dog shit in her yard.  But people get distracted, its very easy for a person to lose focus and stop making decisions about driving and make decisions about numerous other things; radio volume or station, climate controls, what the asshole in the other lane is doing.  When that happens, we make mistakes and it is a very easy thing for a person to do because our decision making speed is far slower then a computer.  Computers won't be better then us at everything, but driving is organized enough to the point where self-driving cars will do it better then us, and in a world where everyone had a self-driving vehicle, accidents would be almost non-existent with cars, lights, everything communicating together, only freak occurrences, like a natural disaster would likely lead to them, and that is what would give job security to steering wheels.  Steering wheels would never be gone entirely because of such freak events that we may still have to override the car for, but those are few and far between.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

author: Milton Waddams

text: +Alan Harake Bro, people said the same thing of cars when they first came out. " Those horseless carriages will never catch on!" But they WILL catch on. It is an unfortunate inevitability for us car guys, as much as it pains me to say.  Already Mercedes and Audi are offering semi-autonomous cars for 2017, and autopilot features will be available for low priced cars by 2020. It will still take about 10-15 years for every car on the road to have some sort of autonomous capability. Most cars will probably still be somewhat driveable ( IE you can switch the autopilot off) until 2030-2040. Depends on how quickly people take to the technology. However, this puts into question the future of driving yourself.If it isn't outright banned at some point in the future, it will be unaffordable to the common man, as the insurance for driving your car manually will be too expensive. manually driven cars will rise in value, pricing them out of the reach of middle class America. Like horse racing, our hobby is destined to become a thing for the rich, and relegated to racetracks and private road courses. I would HOPE we can still drive forever, i would love to keep driving and working on my classic cars as long as I live because I LOVE driving. But we should probably face the reality, gentlemen....we are likely living in the end of an era. We should enjoy it while we still can. You know, just in case.Ôªø
author: Josh Nixon

text: @Josh Nixon¬†- We will be driving for awhile still, many years likely because even if self driving cars come out, they will have it as an option. ¬†It will be a ways down the road (pun intended) that we won't have a choice, and that won't happen until a few things happen; most cars on the road are self driving, they can communicate between themselves and the traffic lights and other signals, and the technology gets to the point where its cheap and reliable and implemented in VERY new vehicle. ¬†That point in time will be many years off, MANY years. ¬†But is this even a likely reality? ¬†With the size of car culture and the amount of people that enjoy driving as a hobby, with vehicles like motorcycles on the roads, will self driving cars ever be a mandatory thing? ¬†No, we will never be forced to have self driving cars. ¬†As nice as it would be to have all self driving vehicles communicating meaning accidents could be eradicated besides natural disasters, that could never happen with the size of car culture, you would be forcing millions upon millions of people world wide to not be able to enjoy their hobby, racing would cease to exist, it would kill car companies like Ferrari, Lamborghini, Pagani, and most other expensive "Driver's Car" type brands, brands that would survive would be like Bentley, but only their luxury lines, Rolls Royce, and everyday drivers. ¬†Self driving will always be an option, even if it comes standard on all vehicles at some point, it will never be something that we have to use. ¬†That and people will always have non-self driving cars, we keep Model T's, and everything else on the road right up to modern cars, so there will always be people with non-self driving vehicles that would make a utopia of only self driving cars impossible. ¬†It just simply can't happen, period. ¬†So don't worry, you will still get to drive your cars, have your classics, although we will eventually run out of fossil fuels, then you will have to get creative.Ôªø

author: Josh Nixon

text:
@KlockworXMusic
Car culture will die in the future generations. You're talking about people who live now, you can't speak for people who are now less than 10 years old.

You will have racetracks for cars where you can drive, similar thing happened to horses. Horses were and to some extent still are used in some poorer rural places.

Like others have said, you will maybe allowed to drive cars but expect to spend a fortune on insurance because a human driver is multiple times more dangerous.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†- Car culture never dies, it has always been around and always will be. ¬†Look at Gran Prix Racing, how old it is and how far its come and is still going. ¬†You look back even at motorcycles and people back in the day making cafe racers, how that style is still around. ¬†Saying car culture will die is ignorant. ¬†You look at car people now, you look at kids in high school, jr. high, elementary; kids still love cars. ¬†And you can speak for people less then 10 years old, car culture and a love of cars does not die over night, it does not die over several years, its something that does not die. ¬†Cars are hobbies, to work on, to drive, they are pieces of art and they are collectibles.

As for race tracks, yes, there will always be tracks to drive unassisted.

Not necessarily. ¬†There are always going to be people who won't be able to afford new cars, self driving cars, there will always be people without them, and initially insurance will likely start out higher on self driving cars due to concerns about safety, and overall cost of the vehicles. ¬†At some point these will likely even out, but its unlikely that normal vehicles will have higher insurance then self driving ones.

Lastly, there will never be solely self driving cars, it will always be a function that can be turned on or off by the driver because this falls into Asimov's 3 Laws of Robotics loosely as well as other ethics concerns regarding robots and computerized systems. ¬†They will never make a vehicle that is only self driving because at that point you take all control away from humans, if there is a problem with the computer, you have no way to override. ¬†Its similar to the questions of "Can we let robots solely make decisions when to pull the trigger?". ¬†Making a car that has no steering wheel, pedals, no overrides falls under the same criticisms, the same controversy as that. ¬†And because everyone will still need to know how to drive in case they have to override a malfunctioning vehicle, people will still know how to drive, steering wheels and controls will always be present in cars and insurance won't go up on non-self driving vehicles because there will always be a need for human control at some point in the road.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
You're being silly. All these things are temporary. Cars have only been around for a little over a century - that's NOTHING.

Before cars guys had horses to compare and to brush. "My horse is the best horse", how many do it nowadays?

It's funny how you think automated systems all depend on people overriding commands. Guess what, huge amount in our daily lives is completely automated and if they have "overriding" capability it's never used. Same will go with cars but it won't be made easy because you don't want a bunch of unstable overconfident humans driving around in potential murder weapons.

Your reply is funny because you seem to completely ignore anything that happened before the last 80 to 100 years.

Vast majority of people drive because it's their job or they want to go to a place, they don't care for the experience except for comfort. The day I can use my laptop to work while in traffic and do my stuff instead of staring at the butt of another car, I will be a happy man.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†- Not being silly, its the facts. ¬†It may not be the exact field I work in, but I know other Electrical and software engineers working on these projects, they are already facing problems, criticisms and ethics dilemma of how far self driving vehicles can be taken. ¬†And you are being ignorant.

Lots of people keep and care for horses still, all over the world. ¬†There are places where the horse hasn't even been obsolete because of cars yet because they have not even gotten cars, and can not afford them. ¬†Assuming everyone will have a self driving vehicle in the next 100 years is foolish.

Cars may have only been around for a century, but they have amassed a HUGE fan base, sure there are casuals that would be alright with self driving vehicles, there are tons of people that won't though. ¬†The wait to get ticket to be some of those people that stand in the audience of Top Gear episodes borders 21 years. ¬†Nothing has amassed popularity and held it like cars have. ¬†but even things not nearly as popular and around longer still exist; civil war reenactors, penny farthings, stationary engines. ¬†They still have people that take interest in them, and they have been around longer and were never in nearly the popularity cars have been.

As for overrides, many things they are installed on are safety features for people to use in case of emergency or incur a fine if used. ¬†But in self driving cars, people will use it as they please, many people won't feel comfortable with a car driving itself, others will still want a driving experience.

And if you think self driving vehicles are no big deal, any car roughly 2010 or newer can be hacked remotely from a laptop and controlled by it while disabling all the controls in the car, including steering and the pedals. ¬†Its truly disconcerting when you press the brakes and the car does nothing, because someone else is driving you around in it. ¬†Self driving vehicles are going to emerge, but they are not going to take over, everyone will not be driving one, they will not have lower insurance and they will not be solely self-driving.

We are not 5 years off from some robotic Utopia where everyone lives like they do on Elysium, where robots do everything for us and life is perfect. ¬†Robots are built by people, people are inherently imperfect, there will always be flaws.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
Nothing has amassed popularity like cars? I beg to differ. Younger generations don't care about cars that much.

Sure, first self-driving cars will have "override" but as the automation gets better and better, this function will be ignored and eventually removed. All programming is automation, how often does Facebook or Amazon fail you? Me? never.

Hacking only applied to certain models and it was early tech. You don't seem to understand that technology can be very buggy in the prototype years but eventually becomes very solid.

Yes, there are always flaws. So what? Human drivers are riddle with flaws! from lack of sleep to drugs to talking on the phone to being careless - all these are flaws. At least when it comes to computers, there's almost always a fix but with humans, there's not.

I will see automated cars become majority in many cities during my lifetime and I'm glad. Private cars will be much rarer as they are usually just a waste of space - instead we will have automated Uber type services.Ôªø

author: Milton Waddams

text: @infiltr80r¬†- "Hitler won't kill 6 million Jews" yeah, a lot of stuff happened people didn't think would, but this falls into major ethics problems as well. If 2 self driving cars collide and kill people, who is at fault? ¬†Oh, no one, too bad so sad you tell then grieving families. ¬†Insurance companies would be non-existent in your world, at least for autos because no one would ever be at fault. ¬†As well, you are not a electrical engineer or software engineer, you don't build these things, you have no concept of how much red tape there is to push this stuff through, and then we have not had it very long. ¬†Bath salts and cocaine have at one point also been completely legal to buy, sell and use before we understand the ramifications of them. ¬†But we are past the point where we put lead in paint (usually) and cocaine in Coca Cola. ¬†We have the foresight to test things first, or to consider at least some of the consequences. ¬†We sterilize space craft before launch like the Voyager 1 so if it does crash into another planet at some point (And it could, its headed off into deep space now) we don't need to introduce anything form Earth to another world and fuck it up, nor if we get a chance to visit other planets, we don't want to be wondering about if the life that exists there was because of us. ¬†When it comes to self driving cars, governments have not created any laws about them yet, we have little test data on them. ¬†Not to mention with terrorism being a thing, if you have solely self-driving vehicles and no over-rides, if a terrorist group detonated an EMP, or more likely a nuclear device, the electromagnetic pulse they produce would render every single vehicle that didn't manual control useless, it would wipe out all the computers in it. ¬†By making everything computerized you open up a massive problem with terrorism, or even meteors. ¬†The meteor that blew up over Russia a few years back, again, produces electromagnetic pulses. ¬†When you get down to the nitty gritty of it, doing it your way, a computerized world, you make massive assumptions about many things you do not even understand or would think about. ¬†Will they catch on, probably, will they completely take over, no way in hell, if they do, you and I will be long dead and forgotten about. ¬†We are not at a point, and will not be at a point to have nothing but self driving vehicles for over a hundred years. ¬†Like I am an electrical engineer, I guarantee you probably have something electronic you can thank me for in your home, but as much as I like ¬†electronics and computerized systems, I can say that solely self-driving vehicles will not be some game changing, revolutionary new tech that will make everything else obsolete. ¬†We had bicycles before cars, cars never made bicycles obsolete, motorcycles and cars have co-existed, and motorcycles in developed countries are primarily a luxury, a toy. ¬†Fuel injection has been around since the 1950's, it really hasn't taken off until the last 20 years, but it hasn't made carbureted vehicles obsolete. ¬†Mechanical timing is still relevant. ¬†There has not been a feature on a car that has made everything before it obsolete, and vehicles with self-driving technology will not make everything else obsolete either, and we have had far greater and more important advancements in technology for cars then self driving cars. ¬†There is a reason why with everything we have come up with, the written language and the printing press are considered the greatest advances in technology we have ever come up with.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text: @infiltr80r¬†- Also as far as your argument when does Facebook or Amazon fuck up? ¬†With surprising regularity. ¬†Remember that time someone found a bug that with a couple lines of code in an infinite loop could have deleted every picture, every video, every profile on Facebook? ¬†Yeah, there are all sorts of bugs in Facebook and Amazon and every other website out there. ¬†If someone found a hole like that with cars, and instead of reporting it, exploited it, you could theoretically destroy every car on the planet by sending it out of control, injure or kills people on a scale not yet seen. ¬†And you can say, well they will think of that. ¬†I am sure Facebook thought they were pretty safe too, and there are always people trying to find ways in, nothing is ever safe until you get to quantum encryption. ¬†But then again, we just don't understand enough about it yet, someone will find a way, someone always will.Ôªø

text:
@KlockworXMusic
No, I don't remember that time, refresh my memory. Sounds like you're making it up. No, all cars don't HAVE to be online - they can be electric and "intelligent" to surroundings but they don't have to t connect to the world wide web.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†-¬†http://mashable.com/2015/02/12/facebook-photo-deletion/#smxEEdGsD5qU

Vehicles would need to be online and communicating within a few blocks of anything around it though to have any chance at beating a human. ¬†Everything thinks computers are so fast and smart and can do anything we tell them too, but they are very limited in some regards. ¬†Humans are far better at a lot of things, but if we narrow that down to general areas, there are 3 things we can kick the living shit out of computers at; unstructured problem solving, acquisition and processing of new information, and most importantly, non-routine physical tasks, which includes driving. ¬†

Unstructured problem solving is solving problems when rules are not clearly laid out, there are exceptions or rules are non-existent. ¬†In driving, this can be modeled with something as simple as 2 people come to a 4 way stop and stop at the same time. ¬†We normally know that the person to the right goes first then. ¬†But this is a rough rule, in a computers world, we can be talking thousandth of a second, they would need to communicate to have that accuracy, otherwise based on sensors like ultrasonic or infrared range finders to figure if they or the other car stopped first would be inaccurate. ¬†The inaccuracy would mean that both cars could think they got there first and start driving. ¬†They would need to communicate so that at least the implement the rule "The person to the right goes first".

Next is acquisition and processing of new information. ¬†Humans do this incredibly well. ¬†Computers, not so much surprisingly to many. ¬†When we look around we see people, and it doesn't matter what they are wearing, or if they are in costume, we know when its a person. ¬†We understand what is a shadow, whats not, we have actually not the best depth perception (we judge things better side to side then forward or backwards) but we do it well enough that in fog or heavy snow fall that we can't see very far and slow down. ¬†Computers using camera recognition suck at this comparatively and would be at a disadvantage. ¬†Having vehicles communicate would mean they wouldn't necessarily need to see the other vehicles to know where they are, besides that you wouldn't have to store a massive database of things on every car, it could be online. not only that, when a car sees something new, it could be added to the data base so every car could use that data. ¬†I mean, a self-driving vehicle will at some point (and will likely have it happen with some frequency) come across something completely new to it.

Now the big one, Non-Routine Physical Work. ¬†This usually consists of very low skilled work as far as humans are concerned, like cooking. ¬†When we cook, its not a hard task, irritating maybe because some of us are lazy, but difficult no. ¬†But its non-routine, and we don't really realize it probably. ¬†We make changes to temperature, stirring, flipping, cook times, all sorts of variables even for the same dish we have made before based on how it is cooking, whether we taste it or it starts to burn a bit, etc. ¬†For a computer, this high degree of variance completely hands it its robotic ass. ¬†It has to tell if something is burning, if its fully cooked, if the temperature is too high for something that is maybe cream based, variances in the temperature of the cooking element (most ovens and ranges vary by 30 degrees or more above and below what you set them too, we don't even think or realize this and cook just fine a computer watching the temperature fluctuate that much would be doing massive calculations to get the timing right). ¬†Driving is the same way, we take driving for granted as a very simple task, and for us it is. ¬†But the way a computer works it is very difficult. ¬†When we drive along, if we see kids playing with a soccer ball in the front yard, we know to watch for them, or if a soccer ball is kicked into the road we know what it is and what is likely to happen AFTER it (A child comes running out after it) and we stop. ¬†A computer sees a soccer ball, recognizes it as an obstacle, slows or tries to avoid it, but it will likely not think ahead that a child might come running out. ¬†Yes, you could program it so whenever it sees a ball on the road surface that it stops incase a child jumps out too, but someone has to program that, and then you get into all sorts of what if this happens that need to be programmed into. ¬†And that is really what it comes down to, we learn and make decisions quickly for non-routine things, think ahead, a computer can make far faster decisions, but for routine things that happen over and over again without having to learn new things or think ahead of what will happen next, which is why in production robots are great, robotic arms fitted to weld cars on assembly lines are great, they do the same weld in the same spot the same way each time, computers are great for that. ¬†Things where there are infinite possibility of things that could and at some point will happen, and having to decide on that takes massive processing power. ¬†And again, communicating cars would help this, a car in front recognizes a ball rolling toward the street as it passes by and warns the vehicles behind it to slow down and be alert. ¬†So again, vehicles would work orders of magnitude greater being able to communicate, if they can't they will likely be no better and probably worse then us at driving, or might match us at slow speeds (We could take major highways to drive from LA to NY, but the self driving car only drives better then me on slower roads so we are only going to take roads with speed limits of 40mph or less so I don't have to drive).Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
That's not true at all. We already have sensors and lasers to do that, there's no essential need for vehicles to communicate, although it can be beneficial.

Driving is very much routine and for you to say it's "non-routine" is funny. Google self-driving car has been doing great - much better than any human driver and it's not online to my knowledge.

PS. I work with automation and programming daily, what you're describing are easy to solve problems and in fact modern self-driving cars include. So you are bringing out problems that really aren't problems at all.

The kid and ball situation has already been addressed by Google, you need to search for it on Youtube. Basically you're years behind what the current code can already do. The only challenge is very poor visibility combined with extreme temperatures when lasers might have problems.

You're really debating like it's 2006, these aren't problems any longer and no, it doesn't take huge processing power to determine these cases, modern CPUs have more than enough to figure out these situations.

You don't seem to be up to date with self-driving car experiments, they're dealing with REAL traffic with kids, buses, bicycles, dogs, drunk people etc - and they do perfectly well, better than humans.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams
KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
As been said by Google, the drivers almost never interfere. It's funny how people like you think technology is binary, not understanding that things develop over time - there are always teething problems.

Google's vehicles have done MILLIONS of miles, so their accident record is much much better than the cars with drivers.

They also released a video showing how the cameras recognize items and what they could potentially do, I have no idea where you get your information from.

The only problem is extreme weather but in some cases they would do much better than humans. Laser guidance systems are millions of times more efficient than human eyes in low visibility conditions, this alone would save so many lives because of no highway pileups¬† during rain or fog.
I don't know if they have snow/ice detection and how efficient that is but that's also a solvable problem.

All problems you described can be fixed and many things already are, you're not up to date.

Roombas are a terrible product then, it's got nothing to do with automation but their bad product.

Would hate to work with you as nothing gets done, everything is either too hard or impossible. Luckily the future is determined by people who believe they can achieve things and eventually do.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†- I get more done then anyone else because I don't dick around with bullshit that wastes money. ¬†Could you build a keyboard that utilizes energy of each keystroke to charge your laptop for a writer, sure, but its not efficient, cost effective and stupid since the average novelist writing one novel on it would run a laptop for about 15 seconds. ¬†Self-driving cars will not take over by 2020, they are a long way off and they will never completely take over. ¬† I am not saying they won't happen, and its fine people are perusing them, but there are far better things to look into. ¬†Better battery technology, better super cap technology, ways to make electric vehicles far more viable then they are, conserving fossil fuels, or prolonging them until we have a better solution. ¬†Better ways of electricity generation.

As for the Google vehicles, there is also a guy with a 3 million mile Volvo that hasn't been in an accident which is better then 23 vehicles driving 1.5 million miles being involved in 14. ¬†Cameras, lasers, potentials. ¬†You are talking about Google who has invested huge amounts of money into this, like I am sorry I drive a Bentley, but I know the vast majority of people do not and can not afford to drive $100,000+ vehicles. ¬†Nor do they have the money to service them. ¬†Electronics regardless of what they are have a limited life expectancy because most components only have a limited number of cycles they can go through. ¬†Cost of ownership of them could be insane after owning one for 5 years, sensors, computers, connection, wires going, the list is endless. ¬†And 5 years is a pretty reasonable estimate since majority of people do not look after their cars the way they should.

And yeah, Roombas are a terrible product, I agree with that completely. ¬†Too expensive and for the amount of hardware in them they really can only handle the most routine of households; carpet, furniture, no pets or people or whatever. ¬†Frankly they can't even do that very well, I buy them frequently for about $30 and they are dead for some reason or another and they are usually only a year old, but they are fun to hack and they aren't as useless if you program them to dead reckon and add a few more sensors and what not. ¬†Which is really what is stupid about them, the programming on them sucks for covering the entire floor, they just spiral outward until they hit something then start a new spiral.

You seem to be ahead of the curve, I might be a little behind, but I am conservative in anything to make sure it is not released prematurely. ¬†As well, there are problems with many states and even countries wary of self driving vehicles due to all current laws being under the assumption that a human is driving. ¬†The transportation laws will need to be addressed, like who would be in the wrong if two self-driving vehicles collide? ¬†What if someone is killed, maybe a pedestrian? ¬†That some of the things you have said are completely ignorant, like car culture dying. ¬†People will always have cars, no one is going to get a self-driving car and scrap a 1967 Mustang Fastback, especially collectible cars like that. ¬†And saying the younger generation will take no interest in cars is foolish. ¬†People need hobbies, cars, especially earlier cars that people can more easily work on will always have a following.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
I don't recall saying 2020, I agree that's unrealistic. But 2030 is possible for a massive rollout and it becoming the default option by 2035-2040.

Singapore promised this year(!) to have taxis on the road without drivers. Not sure if they will go everywhere but it's something that is happening here and now.

Next generations will be about making their self-driving cars look cool, not different from now.
You misunderstand that it's not about cars, it's about man's trusted companion. It used to be horses - who has the fastest, most loyal, best looking horse. Horses also were valued differently. Then it became cars. Next it will be automated vehicles.
You're missing the point that vast majority of vehicles on the road are utility vehicles and cars to just haul people around. I'm not even considering the trucking industry that will be completely revolutionized.
These Mustang hobbyists are only a small percentage of people and they will be allowed to drive their cars on special raceways in the future.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@‚ô° Kleinr Schmetterling ‚ô° (Liberty Schulz)
It won't be like that in the future. Because of the risk involved. Perhaps it will be like "if you switch off automation and drive yourself, you're automatically presumed guilty in all accidents". Imagine automated cars driving in order, keeping safe distances etc and then a human driver swerve around them speeding and creating dangerous situations, he will make the whole road dangerous because of his actions. Or a drunk human crashing into multiple automated cars.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†- Mustang enthusiasts, lol. ¬†Ford, Chev, Dodge, Chrysler, Pontiac, Buick, Austin Healey, MG, Studebaker, Mercury, Nash, Dusenberg, Hummer, Lambo, Ferrari, Rolls, Cadillac, DMC, Jaguar, Mercedes Benz, BMW, Mini, Bentley, Maserati, Lotus, AMC, Plymouth, Alfa Romeo, the list of collectible car brands is endless, not too mention models. ¬†People that have some sort of car hobby, collecting, driving whatever, make up a fairly large percentage of the population, around 58%.

You are saying in the next ¬†20 or 30 years we need to replace every billion vehicles currently registered and driving on the road with self-driving vehicles, possibly add infrastructure to support them if they communicate (which is a good idea), overhaul every countries entire driving law system. ¬†And you said before none of these would be privately owned, so who is footing the bill for a billion cars? ¬†You and me, like fuck if I can't own it I am not paying for it. ¬†The government, dig every government on the planet deeper into debt? ¬†And then what happens to people who do not live in cities, they just have to wait an hour for a vehicle to pick them up before they go anywhere? ¬†Nothing like ordering a taxi from a farm. ¬†And what about farmers and field operators in this world of no privately owned vehicles, and without a steering wheel, pedals and manual over ride. ¬†How is my uncle going to go drive through his fields to check cattle, where there are no roads, many obstacles and harsh terrain, and same with the field operators out working on pipelines out in the middle of nowhere. ¬†Also, no one is working on self-driving motorcycles, ATVs, side by sides, trikes, etc. ¬†Yet many are street legal as well, and for the US that adds another 5% of the population that own motorcycles (The tracks are starting to get very full at this point). ¬†Or dirt bikes, self driving dirt bikes for the off road enthusiast? ¬†But who will maintain them since nothing is privately owned as well? ¬†I mean if I don't own it, I don't give a fuck if I spill stuff in it or whatever, so they are not going to be looked after very well by people if people don't actually own them. ¬†Not to mention, who builds them, if nothing is privately owned, most auto companies shut their doors for good because the government or whomever foots the bill orders a bunch of cars from one manufacturer and then a replacement occasionally, but there is no reason for companies other then that one to stay operating since people that want to buy more cars and collect cars won't be able to. And taxi drivers all lose there jobs too, as if unemployment wasn't bad enough, lets add even more people to that statistic.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@‚ô° Kleinr Schmetterling ‚ô° (Liberty Schulz)¬†- Yeah, he literally expects in the next 20-30 years we replace a billion vehicles with self driving ones, add infrastructure, overhaul the legal system for driving, occur huge amounts of debt on our governments, have none privately owned, with no steering wheel or manual override what so ever, and that huge amount of people with collector cars give them up or use them only at racetracks, which they aren't aloud to drive to, besides motorcycles, ATVs, side by sides, trikes, etc. ¬†Not to mention the problems this causes for farmers, people that live far from town, or require going off road for work or pleasure. ¬†Not too mention his way of doing it would likely mean one monopolized car company as the rest would close because they can't make money. ¬†Its a very communist way of doing things. ¬†But you know, the Soviet Union under Stalin wasn't that bad was it?

Most car companies estimate they will have a vehicle by 2020 that will be able to drive itself part of the time (highways and straight roads) but some have said that it will be an option, and that its more likely that when it does become standard equipment of vehicles (which is substantially further off) that it will be a large aid to the driver, similar to how we have cars that will jam the brakes if it thinks you will hit something.

But there isn't any reason to argue with this guy anymore, if he had a valid point I would agree, but he doesn't and you can't argue with stupid. ¬†This is just like those solar freakin' roadways everyone jumped on the hype train for awhile back; creative idea, but after crowd funding millions, they flopped, because the science behind them and the feasibility wasn't there. ¬†And that is how you get rich today, have an amazing idea that is just too good to be true (Because it is), most people don't fact check, look at the science or consider every possibility, and you make bank off the stupid and uniformed when it flops.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
I did not say none will be privately owned, ever. I said there will be many fewer privately owned cars. Even now, living in a highly urbanized area, I rather rely on Uber than own a car, with the savings coming from removing the driver, it will be much cheaper and even more people will ditch cars as parking can only become more expensive.

Where's the huge amount of debt for the government coming from? It makes no sense. US government for example spends retarded amounts of money on failed fighter jet projects, some infrastructure for self-driving cars is nothing.

Farmers are a tiny minority and the population of the world is becoming more urban at a very very fast rate. I'm focusing on the 80-90% of people, you're so fixed on the 10-20%.

Your whole message is complete bullshit as you're making up things I never said.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text:
@infiltr80r¬†- "Private cars will be much rarer as they are usually just a waste of space - instead we will have automated Uber type services." ¬†Who is footing the bill on the majority that aren't privately owned? ¬†The government? ¬†I am fixed on every aspect of this. ¬†The argument that horses were obsolete 100 years ago is invalid, we still have horses, many horses,we didn't turn them all into glue and meatballs, so saying everything will be self-driving vehicles is idiotic and everything else will be pretty much tossed out or become a tiny minority is invalid. ¬†If I can;t speak for younger generations, neither can you, you can't say car culture will die out. ¬†Saying people will only be aloud to drive on race tracks is idiotic. ¬†And most of my comments you address very little of the questions I ask.

What happens to farmers, the people that grow/raise our food? ¬†What happens to people that do go off road for work or pleasure? ¬†What happens to all the people that will lose there jobs? ¬†What about motorcycles, ATVs, side by sides, dirtbikes, trikes, and other street legal and off road vehicles? ¬†Seriously who is footing the bill for all of this, 1 billion vehicles replaced, the upkeep of them, the infrastructure for them? ¬†Are you making the assumption everyone is going to love this communistic approach where most people won't own a private car (especially the Americans who love to be free to do what they want)? ¬†But you know, don't answer questions with solid answers and keep calling my argument bullshit.Ôªø
author: KlockworXMusic

text:
@KlockworXMusic
Privately owned meaning there won't be cars owned by individuals, the cars will be owned by Uber like services and companies providing a service.

I don't particularly care about the people who lose their jobs, it's been already happening with many jobs that are "victims" of automation. What happened to all the mail room workers when e-mail became mainstream? What happened to travel agencies when everything went online? They got other jobs, retired or became unemployed. This is not a big deal in a changing economy.

Americans aren't more special than the rest, most will just get automated cars and go where-ever they want.Ôªø
author: Milton Waddams

text: Sometimes it takes the right company with the right product at the right time. Look at the MP3 player. Many companies had tried it before the iPod, but the iPod did it the best. BMW isn't the right company to do self driving cars. BMW, Mercedes, and any other Luxury brand aren't the ones to lead the self driving revolution. Those brands have the notion of high expense. So no one is going to look into a BMW self driving car, because its a BMW its probably to expensive for me anyway, and it would be forgotten but Tesla is a new company that doesn't have any preconceived notions about it. Its only known for one thing. Even if its expensive (which it is) that doesn't matter because most people won't immediately make that connection as they would with a luxury brand, so they look into it, and generate buzz about it. Also you have to consider that with the Tesla its a very unique car. A self driving BMW? thats cool, a self driving Tesla thats all electric and has the equivalent of 500HP? Thats something to remember.Ôªø

Camber yeah, but the 45 degrees on a plastidipped 4 door TSX shit like I saw at a show last month will pass. Camber has been around a long time in Japan with Shakotan and Bosozoku stuff, but the crazy shit that the American stance scene is doing will pass eventually.Ôªø

author: Diax1324

text: +Diax1324 you must not watch a lot of motorsport. wide body kits will die when GT1, 2, 3, 4 , DTM, Formula Drift and Hillclimbers find them obsolete. Wide body kits signify car culture merging with race culture. Track days are becoming increasingly popular and affordable and a lot of car enthusiast are avid fans of motorsport.Ôªø
author: Roland Chelsea1986

text:
@Roland Chelsea1986¬†...
R.I.C.E.

Race Inspired Cosmetic Enhancements=
What you're describing
It's not racing if all you ever do with it is take it to the shop. Tires that are too wide on a light car make it lose grip anyway. The only reason those racecars you mention have wide tires is because of the levels of downforce they have and the fact they weigh quite a bit anyway.Ôªø
author: Diax1324

text: +Troggie42 the body kits from the late 90s died due to lack of functionality. Rocket bunny is not so. just think, there's a Rocketbunny Gt86 GT4 race car out there hanging with boss 302s and m3 GT4s. Wide body kits will always be a thing in enthusiast circles. Take a look at the 2002 e46 m3 gt3, that car has sat up on the walls of so many kids bedrooms (has wide body kit).Ôªø
author: Roland Chelsea1986

text: +Diax1324 I mean yeah, some guys have stanced out wide bodies and can't pull into McDonald's drive though. but my comment addressed the longevity of the trend, not it's misuse. I go to Road Altlanta very regularly(live 45 minutes from there) and I see a lot of wide body kits. some guys and a lot of effort into autocross. if I could afford it I prob would tooÔªø

author: Fifthcell

text:
@Fifthcell¬†1) looks are subjective so to me it looks really ugly but your opinion is different and I can understand that
2) yeah that's the reason I hate hybrids and these "environmentalists" that claim to save the earth but really don't do anything the electricity comes from fossil fuels so you're still polluting and to make the batteries and dispose of them you really pollute the earth, all these hybrids and electric cars don't save the earth and I hate it when people claim so but when it's done for performance I have no problem with itÔªø
author: Random_guyM3

text:
+Toma Turcu 1.) thank you for not being childish about opinions xD
2.) I don't see why people hate on the Prius more than any other slow ugly hybrid/EV, they really are all the same, and tbh, I feel the Chevy Volt is uglier than the Prius.... But then again, it's my opinion so...Ôªø
author: Fifthcell

text: @Fifthcell¬†I don't know but I really don't think that electric is the future bioethanol on the other hand...Ôªø
author: Random_guyM3

text: +Fifthcell i remember when the first Pruis's came about. They were mocked for their look xD (admittedly, nowhere near as bad now than they used to be) but also because people went on, and on, and on about how economical they were... then their apparent ridiculousness became more and more widespread. Celebrities driving these around, saying "its the way of the future!" was actually a pretty funny spectacle. Lastly, the nail in coffin for the people i knew - research at the time showed that the hybrid craze was actually doing a lot worse for the environment, as was more costly to maintain... too many arguments based on things that didn't consider the life cycle of the old batteries.... and there we go. for all those who didn't know xD At least they seem to be getting better... LSS: i agree with you, and I hope the history lesson was interesting (if it was previously unheard of... in which case.... sorry!)Ôªø
